page.title: 03Farming in Woolaston-1985
page.content: Most farming is mixed,sheep, beef and dairy cattle, pigs and poultry are common. The land slopes down to the Severn. At the top of the slope,about 600ft above sea level, the land is mostly forested with some sheep kept for lambs (Welsh cross Suffolks) Midway down slope, mixed farms, dairy herds with some arable growing ley grasses for silage, maize for fodder and fodder beet. Around Woolaston village smallholdings up to 4 acres keep a few animals and grow vegetables. Near the Severn large dairy herds, poultry houses and sheep(Welsh ewes) Changes:EEC cut milk quotas, some farmers switch to beef. Change to larger continental breeds of sheep-less fat.Dairy herds now in large units-100plus (British Fresians)
